title: Detroit Free Press Editor Peter Bhatia Wins Kent State's McGruder Award for Media Diversity
text:
CLOSE

Peter Bhatia (Photo: Detroit Free Press)

Detroit Free Press Editor Peter Bhatia was selected as the recipient of the 2018 Robert G. McGruder Distinguished Award by Kent State’s School of Journalism and Mass Communication (JMC) and the Division of Diversity, Equity for his accomplishments in media diversity. The award was named for the late Robert G. “Bob” McGruder, the Detroit Free Press’ first black executive editor. Jeff Fruit, interim director of the School of Journalism and Mass Communication, praised Bhatia as a “a true champion of diversity and of the journalism profession.”

Bhatia began his role as editor of the Free Press in September 2017 after serving as editor of the Cincinnati Enquirer and regional editor for the USA Today Network’s Ohio Region. While at the Enquirer, he earned praise for promoting projects like the "Accused" podcast, which garnered more than 6 million plays, and for his overall emphasis on coverage of addiction, race, higher education and politics.

Bhatia has lead multiple Pulitzer-Prize-winning newsrooms. He became the first journalist of South Asian descent to run a major daily newspaper in 2010 as the executive editor of The Oregonian and was inducted into the South Asian Journalists Association Hall of Fame in 2007.

“Peter is renowned as a leader who encourages reporting that reflects the diversity of American communities, and he has certainly lived up to that reputation at the USA TODAY NETWORK,” said Maribel Wadsworth, president of the USA TODAY NETWORK. “The McGruder Award testifies to the significance of his work at the Free Press and throughout his career in journalism.”

Bhatia visited Kent State today to accept the honor, which has been given for 14 years as a celebration of diversity. Bhatia also delivered a keynote lecture on media diversity during his visit.
